series.title: The Work of God
series.subtitle: The Personal Implications (Thanksgiving Culmination)
series.coreQuestion: What does it mean to be truly satisfied, and how does Jesus fulfill our deepest hunger?

day.title: The Work of God
day.theme: Understanding that the work God requires is not religious activity but simple, profound belief

content.text: When they found him on the other side of the lake, they asked him, 'Rabbi, when did you get here?' Jesus answered, 'Very truly I tell you, you are looking for me, not because you saw the signs I performed but because you ate the loaves and had your fill. Do not work for food that spoils, but for food that endures to eternal life, which the Son of Man will give you. For on him God the Father has placed his seal of approval.' Then they asked him, 'What must we do to do the works God requires?' Jesus answered, 'The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent.'
emphasis: The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent
Do not work for food that spoils

content.rootMeaning: The crowd asks about the 'works' (plural) they must do, but Jesus points them to a single 'work' (singular): belief. This singular work shifts focus from a to-do list to a to-be list.
content.usageNote: In John 6:28-29, the crowd uses the plural 'erga' (works), but Jesus responds with singular 'ergon' (work), emphasizing that the path to God is not a list of tasks but a single act of trust.

relatedWords.meaning: I believe, I trust (often followed by 'eis' meaning 'into', implying personal commitment)

content.title: The Work of God vs. the Works of Man
content.body:
Jesus begins by diagnosing the crowd's motivation. They are seeking him not because they understood the spiritual significance of his signs, but because he filled their stomachs. They were seeking physical satisfaction, not spiritual truth. Jesus calls them to shift their focus from 'food that spoils' to 'food that endures to eternal life.'

The crowd then asks a very religious-sounding question: 'What must we do to do the works God requires?' They are operating under a works-based mindset. They assume that their relationship with God is transactional — if they perform the right actions, God will reward them. This mindset is at the heart of every religion except for true Christianity. It is the belief that we can earn our way to God through our own efforts.

Jesus's answer is revolutionary. He shifts their focus from the plural 'works' to a singular 'work': 'The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent.' The 'work' is to stop working and to trust in the finished work of another. It is to cease from our own striving and to rest in what God has done for us in Christ.

The focus is not on the quality or quantity of our faith, but on the object of our faith: 'the one he has sent.' This is the essence of the gospel. Salvation is not achieved by our works; it is received by our faith in the work of Christ.
content.keyInsight: The 'work' God requires is to stop working and to trust in the finished work of another — it is to cease from striving and rest in what God has done for us in Christ.

content.title: The Thanksgiving Performance
content.body:
Liam dreaded Thanksgiving. For him, it wasn't a day of gratitude; it was a day of performance. It was the annual family gathering where everyone implicitly compared their accomplishments from the past year. His older brother, a successful lawyer, would talk about his latest big case. His cousin would show off pictures of her new, bigger house. And Liam, a high school history teacher, would feel the familiar pressure to justify his life choices, to prove that his life was just as valuable, just as successful.

This year, the pressure felt even more intense. He had been passed over for a promotion, and his wife, Chloe, had recently decided to leave her corporate job to stay home with their young children — a decision that had put a strain on their finances. He felt like he was coming to the family feast with empty hands.

Later that day, after the meal, Liam found himself in the quiet study, trying to escape the noise of the family gathering. He felt a deep sense of dissatisfaction, a spiritual hunger that the turkey and stuffing could not touch. He picked up an old Bible from the shelf and it fell open to the Gospel of John. His eyes landed on a passage where a crowd was following Jesus, not because of his message, but because he had miraculously fed them.

They asked Jesus, 'What must we do to do the works God requires?' Liam felt a pang of recognition. That was his question. What work did he have to do to prove his worth, to feel satisfied, to be enough?

Jesus's answer cut through the noise in his head: 'The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent.'

It was so simple, so counterintuitive. The work was not to do more, but to believe. To trust. To rest. Liam realized he had been spending his whole life trying to perform the 'works' of God — getting the right job, the right house, the right reputation. He was just like the crowd, seeking the temporary bread of human approval instead of the lasting bread of divine acceptance.

He looked out the window at his children playing in the yard, at the setting sun casting a golden glow on the autumn leaves. For the first time that day, a genuine sense of gratitude began to well up in his heart — not for his accomplishments, but for the simple, unearned gift of his family, his faith, his life. The work was not to bring a perfect life to the feast. The work was simply to believe in the one who had invited him.
content.connectionToTheme: Liam represents the universal human tendency to seek validation through performance and accomplishment, illustrating how we often pursue 'food that spoils' instead of resting in the singular work of belief.

content.title: The Wrong Question, The Revolutionary Answer
content.body: This is a timeless human tendency. We often pursue things that provide temporary satisfaction — wealth, success, approval, pleasure — while neglecting the deeper spiritual hunger of our souls. The crowd's works-based mindset was a misunderstanding of the Old Testament law itself. While the law contained many commands, its purpose was never to provide a means of earning salvation. Its purpose was to reveal God's holy character and to reveal humanity's sin and need for a savior.
content.historicalContext: The crowd's question 'What must we do to do the works God requires?' reflects a deeply ingrained Jewish understanding that righteousness came through keeping the law. Jesus's answer radically redefines the relationship between faith and works.
content.fascinatingFact: From the very beginning, the foundation of a right relationship with God has been faith, not works. Habakkuk 2:4 says 'the righteous will live by his faith,' and Genesis 15:6 records that 'Abram believed the Lord, and he credited it to him as righteousness.' Jesus is not introducing a new idea, but clarifying the true heart of the Old Testament.

content.ancientTruth: The crowd came to Jesus seeking physical bread and a list of works to perform. Jesus redirected them to a single, all-encompassing work: belief in the one God sent.
content.modernApplication: We still come to God with our to-do lists, seeking validation through religious activity, career success, or social approval. Jesus offers the same revolutionary answer: stop striving and believe.
content.connectionPoint: The same hunger for meaning and validation that drove the crowds to seek Jesus for bread drives us to fill our lives with activity and achievement. The answer remains the same: rest in belief.
content.newTestamentEcho: Paul echoes this in Ephesians 2:8-9: 'For it is by grace you have been saved, through faith — and this is not from yourselves, it is the gift of God — not by works, so that no one can boast.'

content.prompt: What 'works' am I trying to do to earn God's favor or find satisfaction, instead of simply resting in the finished work of Christ?
additionalQuestions: What are the 'spoiling foods' you find yourself working for in your own life (e.g., approval, comfort, success)? How do they fail to satisfy your deeper hunger?
What would it look like for you to shift your focus from 'doing the works of God' to resting in the singular 'work of God' — believing in Jesus?
Why do you think it is so natural for us to fall into a works-based mindset? What helps you to rest in the truth of grace?

content.text: God, forgive me for trying to earn what you offer freely. Help me to stop striving and to find my rest and satisfaction in the simple, profound work of believing in Jesus. Amen.

content.commitment: Stop trying to earn your worth. Today, identify one area where you are striving for approval (from God or others) and consciously choose to rest in the truth that the only 'work' required is to believe.

content.name: The Crowd at Capernaum
content.title: The Seekers of Bread
content.description: The crowd that followed Jesus after the feeding of the 5,000. They pursued him across the Sea of Galilee, but Jesus diagnosed their true motivation: they sought him not because they understood the spiritual significance of his signs, but because he had filled their stomachs with bread.
content.keyQuote: What must we do to do the works God requires?
content.lessonForUs: We often come to God with the same transactional mindset as this crowd — seeking what he can give us rather than seeking him. Jesus redirects us from performing works to placing our faith in the one God has sent.

weekInfo.focus: Understanding Jesus as the Bread of Life, the true source of spiritual sustenance, and responding with gratitude
learningObjectives: Understand Jesus's claim to be the Bread of Life
Connect the concept of manna in the Old Testament to Jesus as the true bread
Explore the difference between physical hunger and spiritual hunger
Reflect on the personal implications of finding ultimate satisfaction in Christ
Conclude the 8-week journey with a focus on gratitude and thanksgiving
